title: FirstFT: Elizabeth Holmes found guilty in criminal fraud trial
text:
Elizabeth Holmes, the 37-year-old founder of failed blood testing start-up Theranos, is facing decades in prison after being found guilty by a jury in California of conspiring to defraud her investors.

In one of Silicon Valley's most high-profile criminal fraud cases, the jury convicted Holmes of three counts of wire fraud and one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud.

It found her not guilty on four further counts relating to defrauding patients. The jurors failed to reach a verdict on three remaining charges relating to investors. Holmes can appeal her conviction in the federal appeals court.

The end of the 15-week trial was a landmark moment for Silicon Valley, where Holmes' chutzpah had been widely celebrated after she raised nearly a billion dollars to chase the dream of diagnosing health conditions from a few drops of blood.

Five more stories in the news

1. Apple becomes the first $3tn company The US iPhone maker on Monday hit a market capitalisation of $3tn, after its value rose by $1tn in less than 16 months as the coronavirus pandemic turbocharged Big Tech. Apple's shares rose 3 per cent to $182.86, taking it past the latest milestone, before easing back.

2. NY attorney-general expands inquiry into Trump's business practices Subpoenas were issued for Donald Jr and Ivanka as well as the ex-president in early December, according to court documents filed with the New York Supreme Court on Monday.

3. Warner Music buys David Bowie songbook The $250m deal is the latest move in the frenzy to own music copyright that has attracted billions of dollars from investors. The acquisition spans the publishing rights to Bowie's 26 studio albums over his six-decade career.

4. Political uncertainty, Brexit projected to slow UK recovery Britain will trail other developed countries in its economic recovery from the pandemic in 2022, according to almost 100 economists polled for a Financial Times survey. A majority said living standards would worsen, with poorer households hit hardest by soaring inflation and higher taxes.

5. Hedge funds struggle to attract new money Hedge funds gained 8.7 per cent on average from January to November 2021, according to data provider HFR, trailing the S&P 500's 24 per cent return over the period as big rallies in tech behemoths and a series of market jolts disrupted attempts to lure back investors.

ISM survey The Institute for Supply Management publishes its monthly update on US manufacturing.

Opec meeting The Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies, or Opec+, will decide today whether to go ahead with an increase in output next month.

Covid disruptions Delta Air Lines is expected to drop 200 flights today and tomorrow as surging outbreaks and winter storms leave passengers stranded.

What else we're reading

Will overdose deaths force an end to the US ‘war on drugs'? With more than 270 people dying every day of drug overdoses, authorities are under pressure to treat, rather than prosecute, users. But such a move is politically risky for Democrats, as Republicans cast the Biden administration as soft on crime ahead of November's midterm elections.

Investment in Brazil In contrast with the government's more vaunted plans for structural economic reforms, which have floundered for years in Congress, Brazil's programme to attract private companies to invest in oil and gas infrastructure has boomed.

The fertility industry may be giving women false hope The pandemic baby boom may be a bust, but it has led to a rise in the number of women choosing to undergo fertility preservation treatments. But egg freezing is expensive, invasive and comes with low odds, writes Elaine Moore.

Electric vehicle milestone The latest prototype from German carmaker Mercedes has broken the 1,000km barrier with its latest prototype, far beyond the industry average of about 300km. A modified version will be available from 2024 or 2025.

Using AI to predict medical conditions Last month, a physician and machine learning scientist at the University of California, Berkeley, unveiled a treasure trove of unique medical data sets, each curated around a medical mystery. The project could help to train computer algorithms to predict medical conditions earlier, triage better and save lives.
